Award.AwardTitle: "Multispectral Plasmonic Interferometry: A New Tool for High-throughput, Real-time Detection of Cytokines"

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Pacifici
1159255
Leveraging recent progress in plasmonics and nanophotonics, the aim of the proposed research is to develop a dense, planar array of nanoscale plasmonic interferometers for real-time, sensitive, multiplexed, and high-throughput characterization of a variety of cytokines released, e.g., in polytrauma patients. The novelty of the concept being proposed is a new design for multi-wavelength plasmonic interferometry coupled to surface chemistries that are specific to cytokines in order to provide the required selectivity. The result will be a large, dense array of plasmonic interferometers that, while retaining the ultimate sensitivity, could expand the capabilities of current SPR techniques to include broad-band wavelength detection, for specific analyte fingerprinting, and high-throughput characterization, via integration of more than one million SPR-equivalent sensors per square centimeter in a single chip. In addition to a better understanding of light-matter interaction at the nanoscale, the proposed research will dramatically impact the throughput capabilities of several analyses and assays relevant to human health and currently used in the life sciences, and serve as an alternative high-throughput scheme for faster drug discovery, as well as more efficient identification and screening of novel therapies. The proposed research will also provide graduate-level training of students in areas of national need, with particular attention to attracting and retaining underrepresented minorities and women in science and engineering. In addition to the education outreach to local schools, the PIs will recruit a high school summer student to perform sensing experiments using the proposed plasmonic interferometry approach.

NSF-1159255: Outcomes

Multispectral Plasmonic Interferometry: A New Tool for High-throughput, Real-time Detection of Cytokines

The demand for clinical testing of inflammatory biomarkers in serum has increased significantly because of their strong correlation to predicting the clinical course and outcome of trauma patients. This demand arises from the fact that a physician must make a decision on the timing and type of surgical treatment for a polytrauma patient in the absence of real-time data. As such, these decisions are susceptible to human error, which can lead to systemic complications such as multi-organ failure and death of the patient. Currently, cytokine levels in serum are measured using commercially available enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA) or surface plasmon resonance (SPR) techniques. Both approaches are relatively low-throughput and are typically affected by long turn-around times, which are unsuitable for emergency care. This project has expanded the capabilities of real-time SPR-based biosensors by using novel micrometer-scale planar plasmonic interferometers to measure various biochemical analytes with (1) high sensitivity to refractive index changes, (2) low detection limit, and (3) ultra-small sensing volumes. The developed sensing platform can be operated in a broad wavelength range and achieve high detection throughput, sensitivity and selectivity. This technology has been specifically employed to detect relevant analytes, such as C-reactive protein, a relevant biomarker for inflammation in the body, and glucose in saliva, for non-invasive sensing and improved management of diabetes mellitus.

Intellectual merit: This project explored the use of plasmonic interferometry to detect relevant biomarkers and biochemical analytes. The research revolved around the concepts of metal surface functionalization, enzyme-driven dye chemistry, microfluidics, plasmonic interferometry, and integration with high-resolution imaging cameras to develop novel sensing platforms. Upon interaction with plasmonic interferometers, light intensity is modulated as a function of wavelength and arm length. Spectroscopic fingerprints and concentration of an analyte are inferred by measuring changes in spectral-resolved interferograms. Simulations were performed to optimize the groove and slit dimensions and study alternative geometries to achieve efficient excitation and controlled interference of surface plasmon polariton (SPP) waves. Biosensing chips with thousands of plasmonic interferometers per squared millimeter were fabricated using an automated script to control the focused ion beam (FIB) nano-milling process. Silver and gold were both used as the active metal film to support propagating SPPs. The active area of plasmonic interferometers was protected by coating the surface with various thin films of dielectric materials, thus improving resistance to analyte exposure and re-usability of the sensor chip. Various schemes that utilize dye chemistry, enzyme-based reactions, and self-assembled monolayers were explored to improve the sensitivity and specificity of the sensor array. Microfluidic channels were optimized to reduce the sample volumes delivered to the plasmonic interferometers down to a few picoliters. The research sponsored by this award has (1) enhanced the sensitivity of plasmonic interferometers using dye-chemistry for C-reactive protein and glucose sensing, (2) extended the applicability of plasmonic interferometry for detection of multiple analytes, (3) performed selectivity tests for C-reactive protein and glucose, (4) integrated plasmonic interferometers with imaging cameras and microprocessors for improved portability, (5) developed alternative geometries for optical and plasmonic interferometry, (6) embedded light emitters onto the surface of plasmonic interferometers to eliminate the need for external light sources, and (7) enabled plasmonic interferometry with incoherent illumination.

Broader impact: The main research thrust sponsored by this award has contributed to deepen our understanding of light-matter interactions at the micro- and nano-meter scale for the development of novel sensing platforms that employ surface plasmon polaritons. There is a great deal of interest in developing portable, non-invasive, ultrasensitive sensors that can measure more than one significant biomarker or biochemical analyte. The proposed research has the potential to positively impact the throughput capabilities of several analyses and assays relevant to human health and currently used in the life sciences, and it may serve as a novel high-throughput scheme for accelerated drug discovery and screening. Several graduate, undergraduate, and high school students were trained and played an active role in the development of the proposed sensing platform.
